{"step_by_step_thinking": "Tetrazolium chloride staining is a technique used to identify areas of myocardial infarction, or heart attack, in autopsy specimens. The stain works by reacting with enzymes in the heart muscle. Viable, or living, cells will stain red because they contain the enzymes necessary for the reaction. Dead cells, such as those in an area of myocardial infarction, will not stain and will appear pale or colorless.", "answer_choice": "D. Pink"}
